Hi Joel,

thanks for your fast response which addressed exactly my inquiry.=
 

First, I want to clarify that even if evolvability can reach a maximum t=
he conclusion of your paper is correct that it can emerge without any press=
ure for adaptation in the individuals. In this regard, my question whether =
a maximum of evolvability exists was more of general nature.

> The way I t=
hink about it currently is that perhaps there is no ultimate tension, and t=
hat evolvability can generally increase without limit. The reason is that c=
analization of low-level mechanisms can act to increase evolvability. For e=
xample, many of the mechanisms behind development are heavily conserved, bu=
t can generate much phenotypic variability through being combined and modul=
ated in various ways. In other words, modulating conserved features of deve=
lopment gives evolution higher-level levers that enable small genetic chang=
es to be amplified and have a large meaningful phenotypic effect. Thus thro=
ugh continued evolution of the genotype/phenotype map, perhaps evolvability=
 can continually increase (through exploiting canalization of lower-level m=
echanisms to generate increasingly high-level features).

Yep, when I read =
this I noted that this is actually also my opinion about generative encodin=
gs. From this perspective, I would also assume that evolvability can contin=
uously increase in the sense that the genome can become more powerful (or m=
ore flexible) in generating new meaningful phenotypes. Maybe my implicit as=
sumption was not correct that evolvability in a phenotype map could be depi=
cted as iso-oriented point-cloud:

left image in http://www.martinpyka.de/w=
p-content/uploads/2013/04/evolvability.png

According to this illustration,=
 increased evolvability would increase the size of the point cloud. I think=
 I had this picture in mind when I argued in my previous post that evolvabi=
lity cannot increase infinitely because genotype-phenotype mappings should =
become instable when a certain degree of evolvability has been reached. How=
ever, maybe a 2d-depiction of the evolvable phenotype-space would rather lo=
ok like in the right image (I am sorry for my poor artwork). Through canali=
zation, not all phenotypes in the 2d-space are evolvable but evolvability i=
tself can still increase!?

Maybe, both pictures can also illustrate what c=
analization means. The left picture could depict all possible points in the=
 genotype space that can be reached through mutation and recombination and =
the right image all possible points in the phenotype space that can be gene=
rated from it. While each bit in the (2d)-genotype has equal probability of=
 been mutated, in canalized encodings only a well-ordered subspace of pheno=
types can be reached.

Thank you for this inspiring discussion. :-) I enjoy=
 thinking about how all this fits together.

Best,
Martin
